Verified Manager10/05/2017

Thank you for the nice review about Colonial Village at Deerfield! We are so happy that you decided to join us here! Thank you again for the positive feedback, and please let us know if there is anything we can do to make your stay with us even better.

How was this review?
Useful
Thanks for voting!
Report
Verified Resident
2017 Recommended Property Reviewed 10/04/2017
I moved into this apartment in mid September, and so far, it has been great. Quiet location, friendly neighborhood, and kind, conscientious staff. Yanisa at the front desk was helpful on the move-in day, and even took me to the apartment to ensure that everything was in good working order in the unit - this has never happened to me on move-in day, and it was greatly appreciated. The manager and maintenance staff are kind, easy to talk to, and prompt with responses to maintenance issues, etc. The Colonial Village online payment and maintenance request service makes it easy to get rent paid, and services completed. The Colonial Village outdoor pool is nice for summer months, but is maintained and kept open throughout the year, which is nice for reading by the pool in any month. The location seems out of the way, but it is still very close to Duke campus, and not far at all from Downtown Durham. The proximity to Duke Forest is ideal for those who enjoy trail runs or just short walks in the woods. The surrounding neighborhood is safe and family/pet friendly. Finally, while the complex is less than 2 mi from Duke and 4 from downtown, there is a GoDurham bus that picks up directly outside the complex, and drops off right across from Duke, and directly in the heart of Downtown Durham. Good choice for apartments.

Verified Resident
2017 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/28/2017
The community as a whole is good. Neighbors are pleasant, atmosphere is good, amenities are reasonable, location is good. The recycling bin, however, is always filled up quickly and then materials are placed on the outside of the container. The capacity could easily be doubled either in the one location or have to recycle containers at opposite ends of the complex. We have had cockroaches on the screened-in porch (I bought baits to put outside) and the HVAC plenum and filter was disgusting (thick dust) which I vacuumed and replaced the filter. I was later told this was available as a maintenance service but it should have been done before we moved in and on a schedule.

Verified Resident

Very conveniently located near Duke Univeristy/Hospitals. Community is very clean and well maintained and they are making improvements all the time. On a few occasions I've had maintainence requests of various kinds and their on site staff is wonderful. They are very nice, answer quickly and make the necessary repairs right away. Front office staff is helpful in taking in packages and answering questions. The pool area is really nice and very clean and while they have a few grills, they are charcoal and not gas, which can be a pain to use. Love the layout of my two bedroom unit (high ceilings, covered porch, fireplace, walk-in closets, 2 baths), but the cabinetry/tops need to be updated. Everything is clean and functional but a bit dated. I think they are renovating units as they turn over as occasionaly residents are offered a move to a refreshed unit. Of course if everything was brand new with granite counters my rent would be a lot higher! Plenty of free parking right near the unit. There are a wide mix of residents from older couples to grad students, young families and singles - it's a safe and quiet environment. Never heard loud parties or arguments. Overall it's a nice place to live. Really hassle free, convenient and a good value for the money. We are happy we chose this community.

Verified Manager08/12/2015

Thank you so much for the great review! We appreciate your feedback and we are thrilled that you chose to make Colonial Village at Deerfield your home.

How was this review?
Useful
Thanks for voting!
Report
Resident
2014 - 2015 Not Recommended Reviewed 08/04/2015
The review part of this comment ends with the star rating. Instead, I think it would be more beneficial to provide a list of things that may be of interest to someone considering this complex. - DOORBELLS. No doorbells for units. Hopefully you are awake when company knocks - MAIL. No mailboxes next to the front door. Mailboxes are housed under a gazebo that is closer to some apartments than others. You gotta make the walk - APPLIANCES. Dated Appliances (dishwasher, stove, fridge, heating dial pad). Models I didn't think made it out of the early 90s. Most of the complexes in the area use electric rather gas stoves. - LEASE TERMS. Inflexible lease terms. You cannot sublet or break the lease without paying exorbitant fees. Somewhere between $1500-$2000 - PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION. Poor public transportation coverage. The public bus runs only once an hour. It has a tendency to run late or off schedule. If you miss it, hurry up and wait. It will take you at least an hour to get to the nearest grocery store by relying on public transportation because you will need to catch a connecting bus that does drive by the nearest grocery store. - PHONE SERVICE/INTERNET. The phone service in Durham is not always reliable but is ESPECIALLY problematic in this complex. Before committing to a unit, please make a few outgoing phone calls with conversation lasting more than five minutes and have people call you in all rooms of the unit. There were weeks were I I had missed ten calls that i wasn't aware of until I was away from the unit. No room had service. The internet speed was the poorest I've ever experienced as well. -HIDDEN FEES. Due to an agreement that the complex has with TWC (apparent cable/internet monopoly in the region), there is a mandatory $50 monthly fee you must pay regardless of if you watch TV or not. Also, make note of where the television hookup is located in the unit. You don't want it in an awkward location that disrupts the feng shui of your living area set up. In addition to the monthly you must pay regardless of whether you have a tv or not, you must also take on a monthly adapter bill for a digital adapter that TWC rolled out as a way to further charge its customers. Finally, there is a mandatory $55 carpet cleaning fee upon move-out. I am probably missing a few more hidden fees. In addition to rent, the complex charges roughly $100 in select utilities (pest/trash/water, etc). This is apart from the utilities you pay to 3rd party utility vendors (electric, wifi, etc. ) - UTILITIES. Water/trash/pest control are stable costs. The one monthly varying cost is electricity which is provided by Duke Energy. At some points, I found myself paying utilities bills that were 30-33% of my monthly rent bill. That should NEVER happen in this area. While that could be based on usage, I was told before I signed the lease and know that colleagues who lived in nicer complexes never paid more than $70-100 in utilities. If you are going to be paying $100 dollars extra a month, you might as well live in a more upscale complex. On the whole, I do not think that complex has done enough to make the place student friendly. They have an opportunity to make themselves the premier choice of students who are looking for a quiet and safe place from which to commute to and from campus but instead, they do the bare minimum. The inflexible lease terms are not conducive to students whose programs call for study abroad or finish before the end of the semester. If you have a car, then you won't have to deal with the headache of the lack of public transportation options in the area. The complex could be proactive in creating an agreement with the university and hospital to set up a shuttle service (like complex opposite them does) but they couldn't be bothered. As such, when the bus is late, students are forced to wait an hour or pay for an overpriced taxi cab because the university's shuttles do not come to the complex. In poor weather conditions, students in this complex are also left hung to dry when the public bus stops operating. This complex is best for young professionals on a budget with a car who want a very quiet and relatively safe complex. Students on a budget without a car? Be careful with this place. Note: Staff responses to comments here are much like their attitudes toward the interior quality of their units - cosmetic. Tenants want 21st century units for their rent, not great outdoor gardening.
The review part of this comment ends with the star rating. Instead, I think it would be more beneficial to provide a list of things that may be of interest to someone considering this complex. - DOORBELLS. No doorbells for units. Hopefully you are awake when company knocks - MAIL. No mailboxes next to the front door. Mailboxes are housed under a gazebo that is closer to some apartments than others. You gotta make the walk - APPLIANCES. Dated Appliances (dishwasher, stove, fridge, heating dial pad). Models I didn't think made it out of the early 90s. Most of the complexes in the area use electric rather gas stoves. - LEASE TERMS. Inflexible lease terms. You cannot sublet or break the lease without paying exorbitant fees. Somewhere between $1500-$2000 - PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION. Poor public transportation coverage. The public bus runs only once an hour. It has a tendency to run late or off schedule. If you miss it, hurry up and wait. It will take you at least an hour to get to the nearest grocery store by relying on public transportation because you will need to catch a connecting bus that does drive by the nearest grocery store. - PHONE SERVICE/INTERNET. The phone service in Durham is not always reliable but is ESPECIALLY problematic in this complex. Before committing to a unit, please make a few outgoing phone calls with conversation lasting more than five minutes and have people call you in all rooms of the unit. There were weeks were I I had missed ten calls that i wasn't aware of until I was away from the unit. No room had service. The internet speed was the poorest I've ever experienced as well. -HIDDEN FEES. Due to an agreement that the complex has with TWC (apparent cable/internet monopoly in the region), there is a mandatory $50 monthly fee you must pay regardless of if you watch TV or not. Also, make note of where the television hookup is located in the unit. You don't want it in an awkward location that disrupts the feng shui of your living area set up. In addition to the monthly you must pay regardless of whether you have a tv or not, you must also take on a monthly adapter bill for a digital adapter that TWC rolled out as a way to further charge its customers. Finally, there is a mandatory $55 carpet cleaning fee upon move-out. I am probably missing a few more hidden fees. In addition to rent, the complex charges roughly $100 in select utilities (pest/trash/water, etc). This is apart from the utilities you pay to 3rd party utility vendors (electric, wifi, etc. ) - UTILITIES. Water/trash/pest control are stable costs. The one monthly varying cost is electricity which is provided by Duke Energy. At some points, I found myself paying utilities bills that were 30-33% of my monthly rent bill. That should NEVER happen in this area. While that could be based on usage, I was told before I signed the lease and know that colleagues who lived in nicer complexes never paid more than $70-100 in utilities. If you are going to be paying $100 dollars extra a month, you might as well live in a more upscale complex. On the whole, I do not think that complex has done enough to make the place student friendly. They have an opportunity to make themselves the premier choice of students who are looking for a quiet and safe place from which to commute to and from campus but instead, they do the bare minimum. The inflexible lease terms are not conducive to students whose programs call for study abroad or finish before the end of the semester. If you have a car, then you won't have to deal with the headache of the lack of public transportation options in the area. The complex could be proactive in creating an agreement with the university and hospital to set up a shuttle service (like complex opposite them does) but they couldn't be bothered. As such, when the bus is late, students are forced to wait an hour or pay for an overpriced taxi cab because the university's shuttles do not come to the complex. In poor weather conditions, students in this complex are also left hung to dry when the public bus stops operating. This complex is best for young professionals on a budget with a car who want a very quiet and relatively safe complex. Students on a budget without a car? Be careful with this place. Note: Staff responses to comments here are much like their attitudes toward the interior quality of their units - cosmetic. Tenants want 21st century units for their rent, not great outdoor gardening. Read less

This property has business practices that I consider to be deceptive and possibly illegal under current Durham housing code. They charge fees for trash, pest control, and administrative fees that are not explicitly mentioned in the lease and then claim they are "utilities." The rent pricing scheme seems predatory (rent doubled when lease went rolled over to month to month lease) and is not consistent for similar apartments in the same complex (i.e. you and the guy next door in an almost identical apartment could be paying as much as $400 difference for the same lease period). Apartments are, in my opinion, substandard for the price. Doors are hung crookedly. There are visible cracks in the walls. Plumbing is poorly designed so that it creates a water hammer when kitchen sink valves are closed. Saw cockroaches in the apartment within the first month of moving into the apartment. Had the refrigerator door break within the first five months. The mangers seemed to frequently not be in the office during business hours.

I've lived here for 3 years. Beautiful, we'll maintained living space/grounds. Moldy smell emanating from the toilet tank, from under the kitchen sink, from the pantry. Windows and doors are very, very DRAFTY. Get ready for cold in the winter and dampness in the summer. It's great having a washer and dryer in the unit, but the dryer takes FOREVER to dry my laundry. When I renewed my lease, the rent went UP $103 per month!! You HAVE to pay for cable TV $50 per month whether you watch cable TV or not. You don't have a choice. The garbage and recycling space is a joke. It's SMELLY and disgusting! I saw one young man tossing his bags up in the air, over the enclosure. Duh! His garbage landed on top of the trash bin. Duh! 2010 - 2012 Recommended Property Reviewed 03/14/2012
When I moved in early 2010, things were a little hairy to put it nicely. I was actually a previous poster on this site about this property. However, Caroline has turned things around dramatically. The maintenance people from Robert onto the new guys are incredible. Same day service with efficiency. If something is broken and they cant fix it immediately they seem to buy new appliances for you. No more waiting month after month on faulty equipment. In fact, the property manager came into my apartment on her day off last week to scrub out a stain on my carpet and then just randomly decided to oil my cabinets as well! A lot of the staff live on the property and so they know when the dumpster is full or a tree has fallen down after a storm etc. I now definitely recommend this place with a few caveats. First, I would make sure to see the exact apt you will move into before you sign. I didnt do this and my apt was rundown and shoddy (pre-Caroline). It seems nowadays when people move out they are replacing carpet, appliances, ect so my case was probably a thing of the past. Also, the corporate office will raise your rent dramatically when you resign. Almost criminal if you ask me. They cant know exactly what it will be each year but be prepared for up to a 10% increase. Sign a long contract if possible.

Every couple of months it seemed like there was a new manager. We stopped bothering trying to learn their names - there just wasn't much point. There was definitely some criminal activity in the area. Our car was never broken into, but our plates were stolen. Like some other reviewers, we had leaks right above us. They apologize profusely one minute and are hostile the very next, even after they screw up, which is WAY more often than not. Sorry in advance for the diatribe, but never in my life has anything remotely like this ever happened to me, and I have many outstanding rental references, so where should I even begin... Constant employee turnover means it will be MONTHS AND MONTHS before anything gets done, if at all. And you can see from reading several of the other reviews (so please don t just take just my word for it! : ) that the property manager is (IMHO) / in my honest opinion as truly low down dirty and dishonest as they can be. She / they have lied to me repeatedly about everything from the age of the water heater (they claimed it was new, although the date on it is from the 1980s) to whether the carpet is new (it isn t, and I regret not having walked out the second she tried to convince me it was), to whether or not they are really committed to even trying to fix the significant damages caused by their own subcontractors last year during the huge pipe replacement debacle. In late 2010, the leasing manager hired local third-party plumbing contractors to replace pipes throughout the entire apartment, which caused significant damage to my apartment by leaving a thick layer of powdered drywall dust everywhere, pipes that were left completely exposed for months on end, excess paint spray that got all over and ruined the cabinets, as well as blackened finger- and hand-prints, and even miscellaneous smudges and scrapes that were also left all over the walls after they banged around equipment such as their shop-vacuums, etc., on nearly every single wall. They even carelessly poured a decent-sized blob of white paint on the filthy beige (allegedly "new") carpet, yet the icing on the cake was when they threw away my $35 ultra-fancy shower head without any regard whatsoever for anyone else s property. Further, the flat front panels of two separate kitchen drawers (cheap pressboard cabinetry) fell apart all on their own within months of my moving in, so it distinctly gives one the very charming impression of living in a crack den since they are nearly disintegrating and cannot be super-glued anymore. But believe me, I would definitely rather try to fix anything myself as opposed to remaining at the mercy of having to bother anyone in that office because they act like they are doing you a favor to even listen to you for 30 seconds. Due mainly to the high employee turnover and the office personnel that cannot even be bothered to return multiple phone calls or messages, they even reneged on their verbal promise to provide me with a cleaning person after the kitchen and both bathrooms were rendered completely useless for approximately 1 week, and dust got EVERYWHERE (even in my electronics 15 feet away and/or in another room) because they were just careless and also didnt have enough drop cloths. I was also told by the maintenance supervisor that I would have to do the touch-up painting all by myself, even though I didn t cause any of this damage whatsoever. After all of this, they fired their leasing manager and then immediately tried to coerce me to work directly w/ the 3rd party contractors so they could do the repairs, so the contractors of course laughed and called the office manager a bunch of four-lettered words to me on the phone before telling me that my only viable option was going to be to call the leasing office back since they (the contractors) claim that they had performed beyond the scope of the duties outlined in their own contract for the pipe replacement. Still nothing has gotten done, and it has been 7-8 months now since the extensive damages to my apartment. So, after I had made exactly two in-person visits to the leasing office, left 10-plus voicemails which were never returned, and sent more than 12 separate emails, I didn t want to believe it but I finally realized that the only thing you can really count on would be the property manager's uncanny ability to bat her eyelashes while apologizing profusely and repeatedly promising to help you as she comes up with excuse after excuse after excuse as to why nothing is her fault, thereby failing not once but repeatedly to follow through on even one single thing. So, after I had made exactly two in-person visits to the leasing office, left 10-plus voicemails which were never returned, and sent more than 12 separate emails, I didn t want to believe it but I finally realized that the only thing you can really count on would be the property manager's uncanny ability to bat her eyelashes while apologizing profusely and repeatedly promising to help you as she comes up with excuse after excuse after excuse as to why nothing is her fault, thereby failing not once but repeatedly to follow through on even one single thing. Nevertheless, although she appears to be quite sweet and congenial the first time you meet her b/c she obviously wants your ($) $,$$$.$$, she unequivocally strikes me as the most two-faced and dishonest person I ve ever met who has zero problem lying right to your face (IMHO/in my honest opinion). But there are other serious issues such as the maintenance personnel that effectively broke into my apartment 3-4 times in the absence of any kind of emergency and without my consent, and this was even after I warned them following the 1st incident. So this, in addition to all of the other unresolved issues that were never addressed, convinced me to call their corporate office in Birmingham, Alabama (TEL # 1-205-250-8700), but only after they repeatedly failed to address every single repair issue, other than to spend just 5 minutes fixing 1 of 2 toilets that ran constantly and caused my water bill to more than double for many months straight while they kept missing scheduled appointment after scheduled appointment, and so on. After that, and I really felt I had no other choice in that I had literally been as patient as any reasonable person could be (even begging them at one point and half-heartedly offering to bribe the maintenance guys with a case of beer each), but then I was blackballed and became persona non grata, actually just today receiving an email that effectively kicks me out by saying (paraphrased) that I would be "better off locating a different property in which to live." In addition, at first I truly gave them the benefit of the doubt and offered to work ***entirely*** around their schedule to fix the repairs, and so they set up (at first) THREE different appointments with specific dates and times times, and they missed every single one of them, one by one. I left work on each occasion, came here, waited, and no one even had the courtesy or the sense to give me a heads-up (much less to apologize) even once, so I was not happy having to go back to work and add on at least an hour if not longer to the end of my day to compensate for being absent during regular working hours. My boss even told me that he was not going to tolerate anymore workday excursions for these people (and of course they don't do work on weekends), so I very much began to worry that my job was in jeopardy, even though I know my boss knows I am a good employee and had zero control over this. If that's true, then it's a complete miracle if they have any teeth left. So I then decided they would work around my schedule, and, after agreeing to meet me at specific dates and times, they still missed multiple scheduled appointments to which they had not only agreed but also already confirmed. My neighbor's apartment (she's a single female) was broken into the same day the contractors finished their work, and the property manager refused to notify other tenants in the same bldg of the break-in for weeks and weeks (i.e., so they could take steps to protect themselves - e.g., getting window alarms, etc.), and all of this is according to my neighbor, so WATCH OUT SINGLE LADIES b/c they will protect & accommodate contractors before they will lift a finger to help residents. Least of all, I think there is a homeless person storing his belongings behind their storage shed directly across from my apartment (although he just recently started showing up and only seems to come out in the middle of the night). She promised me that if I signed the lease before a specific date I would get one free wall paint, one free carpet cleaning, 50 dollars off, and several small gifts like a stainless bottle and the stuff. But three days later, when I finally moved in and went to the office, she simply told me that she made a mistake and I could only get one free carpet cleaning, then refused to give any further explanation. I did not want the gifts that badly and I was new in the country so I did not argue at all. But later I found out that, not only they don't honor their promotion offers, it is their corporate culture to rip off their residents with any chances given. My water tank started leaking more than half a year ago, it took them three months to have the water tank finally fixed completely, mainly because they don't want to spend the money to buy the new parts to replace the old valve. So I have to call the maintenance people in once every couple of weeks. If I know how, I would simply buy the parts and fix it myself. For now I am just waiting for my lease to expire and leave this place, because they charge you an exorbitant amount of money to move out early. So don't rent from them!

Resident
2011 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/28/2011
I moved up here to be with my girlfriend, who wanted to get a new place together, so we found this place about 6 months ago and immediately signed a lease. The staff seemed pretty disorganized as there was not a property manager in the beginning, and they dropped the ball on some work orders that were not completed until four months later. It was also hella annoying that they continually sent us collection letters when it was later determined were incorrect because we had a zero balance. Overall, the people in the office have been rude and pretty much inept (especially the property manager, whose name I think is Carolyn), not to mention extremely difficult to deal with all along. While it didn't look that bad in the beginning, nearly all of the equipment in the gym is broken and has been that way for the entire time we've been here. The worst part is that my girlfriend is now desperately trying to talk me into paying the lease termination fee, which is several thousand dollars - NOT cheap, so we can move somewhere safer because her car was broken into two times already because there are many malfunctioning lights on the property. However, the thing that really pushed her over the edge was when we started seeing these freaking massive cockroaches on the walls and ceilings after the weather started getting hot, but mostly at night. (Seriously, I am not even kidding you ... these things were HUGE = as long as my girlfriend's index finger, therefore at least 3 1/2 inches in length.) One night several weeks ago, she was brushing her teeth in the bathroom at around 11:30 pm, and suddenly I heard her run out of the bathroom and down the hallway screaming like a maniac the entire time. When she stopped running, she was practically going into convulsions trying to take her shirt off, and it turns out that a 3 1/2 inch long and 1 inch wide cockroach had fallen from the bathroom ceiling onto the back of her neck, and slid down her shirt. Ever since then, she refuses to go into the bathroom at night and insists on sleeping with a kid's night-light on in the master bedroom. I have called the leasing office several different times to request an exterminator, but it hasn't happened so far. One time they forgot to actually put in the request, so I had to call back a week later, and then they keep telling me it'll be next month (which we have heard several times), and I have to keep calling to stay on them. You must definitely plan to do a lot of follow-up to get these people to do anything, even though I haven't been very lucky so far. Either way, I was really surprised to see cockroaches and dumpster rats (due to infrequent garbage removal) at this place because it looks reasonably okay on the outside. Nothing special, but if we had known what we know now, we definitely would have avoided ever moving in... Hopefully you will be able to learn from our mistakes instead of getting stuck in a year lease like we did, b/c we got RIPPED OFF. :(

They have even gone out of their way to help me with things that i know they didn't have to. So right after I moved I did have my pipes replaced. The process was really annoying. but I get that it will keep something worse from happening. In my old community, my neighbor had a pipe burst in her apartment and her apartment was flooded. She lost pictures, clothes, furniture, almost everything. So i would much rather live with dust for a week instead of not having a place to live and no clothes to wear. Duke Forst surrounds us, so we're blocked from most traffic. I LIKE it here!

I moved in here mid-August and within a week wanted to move out. My fault, I came from California and didn't make the time to fly out myself and physically look at the place. The first time it rained (within 1 week of living here) I discovered that water was coming in through the top of my window sill. The maintenance came over and caulked the outside and said they fixed it. A week later, it rained AGAIN and AGAIN (this time the horrible emergency matenance crew) all they did was caulk the outside and said they fixed the problem. Let's just say it has now been 4 times I have had rain come in through my window and soak my carpet and I haven't even been here 2 mos yet. The "emergency" maintence crew is an outside company apparently and if you call them they DON'T call you back and it took the guy about 2.5 hours to show up! GIANT bugs (Palmetto Bugs? They look like giant roaches to me) come inside the apartment from I don't know where. The other day one was on my leg!! GROSS!! I've had the exterminator come in the apartment and still see them. We always put our food away never eat outside the dining area and keep the kitchen pretty spotless so it's not US! My carpet smells from the rain coming in and they told me it's not mildewing and made no attempt to clean or replace it. Only brought a fan to dry it. The apartment was not cleaned properly before we moved in; the blinds, fixtures, patio, corners were filthy. Management even admitted they didn't walk through before we moved in. One of the apartments upstairs and the one across from us is NOTORIOUS for flooding. Our neighbor said it flooded 8 times before he finally moved and the new neighbors told me it already flooded on them once and they haven't even been there a month. The management is not accomodating at all, they told us if we want to transfer apartments (even on the property) it's a $500 transfer fee. Even though the building is falling apart! We had the city building inspector come out today and he's going to get into the crawl spaces in the building to see if it's being properly maintained (obviously isn't). The management doesn't care or try to really fix problems, they only do quick fixes and tell us "we're sorry you're frusterated but our hands our tied" I can hear EVERYTHING from my upstairs neighbors,from their flushing the toilet to every step they take to their late-night activities and they're not loud people. The walls are paper thin. I've never had so many problems with an apartment EVER!! I PROMISE you I'm not lying I would never make something up, I normally don't write negative reviews on ANYTHING but I just need to let others know...this place is TERRIBLE!! Can't wait to get out of here next month!

I lived at this facility for 2 years and I still believe that it is a beautiful, well designed complex. The problem lies with those who run it. My rent differed greatly from my neighbors in identical apartments. Preferential treatment is commonplace. (As an example, carpet cleaning was made available to some, but not others). Maintenance was absolutely terrible (they let out my cat, failed to fix my garbage disposal or air conditioner after multiple work orders were placed). There were other complications with mold that I will not go into. There was rapid turnover in staffing, so it was impossible to build a rapport with management. In short, I would not recommend this place to anyone.

Resident
2009 Recommended Property Reviewed 04/18/2009
My husband, my son, and I have been living here for a year. We're getting ready to move out at the end of the month, and I can truly say that I enjoyed my stay at CV @ Deerfield. The Good - Safety Great parking Walking/biking trails Within 2 minutes of 147 and 15-501 Nice, roomy apartment Covered deck The Bad - When we first moved here, my husband's car was broken in to, and they took EVERYTHING. Thank goodness my husband's auto insurance covered it! About a month after my husband's car was broken in to, a police officer was chasing someone into the woods...not sure if this person was a resident at CV at Deerfield or what. There haven't been any other incidents since then. I just know not to leave anything in my vehicle in plain view and also not to be out too late at night, because you never know what or who may be lurking in the woods! We also had a molded spot on our ceiling where there may have been a leak in the past. Apparently, the mold was eating at the ceiling, and we ended up having holes and terrible peeling - pieces of mold/mildew were falling onto my countertop! We got maintenance on it, and all they did was painted over it. Now, the holes are coming back again and the mold is once again eating away at the ceiling. Not sure what they need to do about this, but it was pretty obvious to me that paint wouldn't cover it.

Resident
2006 - 2009 Recommended Property Reviewed 01/16/2009
We've lived here 2.5 years and have been very happy. As a Duke grad student, this has been an ideal location. It's in a relatively quiet and safe area. We live on the top floor and haven't had any problems with noise. There's plenty of parking. We loved the screened in porches. Probably the best part about it to me is the access to running trails within the complex and nearby neighborhoods. I trained for 3 half marathons while living here with ease. It's a little older than some of the other complexes, but a good value for the money (even though the rent has increased quite a bit while we've been here; and they make you buy their cable... that is kind of annoying) Management has changed hands a lot of times which is kind of frustrating, but when something is broken, they get in and fix it pretty quickly. I would not hesitate to recommend living in this complex. We're moving out soon to live in another area, and I will definitely miss it.

Resident
2006 - 2008 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/01/2008
I have lived at Deerfield for a bit over two years. On my move-in day, I learned that the management lied to me (and would continue to do so) by putting in a washer and dryer that I had asked not to be installed (since I had my own). They tried to lie their way out of it, despite my having proof in writing that the apartment hadn't had a W/D when I looked and that I had not requested one. They then tried to get me to sell me W/D instead of removing theirs. Only the presence of the maintenance guy, who offered to fix the situation, cut off the management. The woman who rented me the apartment had promised several other fixes - replaced carpets, a new dishwasher - that I was too trusting to get in writing; these problems were not remedied, nor have they ever been. When I went to renew my lease, they tried to bump it up $100/month, despite promised that it would only be an increase of $10 to $40. After much work, I was able to persuade the management to approximate their promise and raise my rent by only $50 a month. Recently, I have had a problem with flooding. 10 months ago, a pipe in my ceiling burst and flooded my apartment and the apartment below me. One week ago, it happened again, and then again just last night. One person in the office has been helpful, kind, and understanding about the situation. The manager of the complex, however, has been unhelpful and arrogant. The location of Deerfield is very nice; being surrounded by Duke Forest makes it so that I can hear locusts, songbirds, and owls. There are decent hikes and running trails nearby. Three nights ago, I saw a deer right next to my building, grazing on a bush. In my opinion, the best feature of my apartment is the screened-in porch (one of which every apartment has). If you decide to rent here, make sure that you get everything in writing and be wary of the management.

Resident
2007 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/05/2007
Me and my husband moved into Colonial Village at Deerfield 1 year ago. We are renting a 2Bed and 2Bath, ground floor apartment for $825 a month. The place looks really inviting from the outside but inside the properties are failing fast. We have had nothing but problems from Day 1. We first arrived to find out the place was infested with Cockroaches. The maintenance guy tried to fob me off by telling me they were Water Bugs. Water Bugs sound so much nicer but basically they are cockroaches and they fly - right at you. Then the A/C broke just when we had temps 100F plus and high humidity. It defrosted and totally flooded the hallway carpet and took forever to dry. It took a couple of weeks for the musty smell to go away. It also took several attempts by the maintenance guy to get the A/C working the way it should. Back in August 07 there was a major water leak in the apartment above us and being on the ground floor we ended up with all the water in the kitchen and 2nd bathroom. We came back in time before it had spread into our living area and luckily none of our stuff got damaged. However, the water has caused damage to the ceilings in the kitchen, 2nd bedroom and living room. The down stairs carpets were totally soaked (and stinking like a sewer) and we had to move out into the 'guest apartment' courtesy of Colonial Village. We had to wait 3-4 days for the carpet to dry and we finally got to move back in. We were in for one night and now another pipe has burst, this time in our apartment, and the carpets are soaked yet again and the place is stinking AGAIN. It is only a matter of time before the mold and mildew set in and I dread what the place will look like in a couple of months. The general attitude of the staff working here is 'Oh well, the place is 10-15 years old and you should expect wear and tear'. They should of told that to the guy upstairs who's ceiling collapsed last week. I was also told 'you should expect bugs because we do live in the woods and if you have dirty neighbours it will attract them too! To give them credit, the management staff have got on to try to solve our problems by providing us with huge dryers/fans and moving us to alternative accommodation. However, the general attitude is 's***e happens and you have to just get on with it. I did mention that I was expecting some kind of compensation but I will not hold my breathe. Do yourself a favor and do not even consider renting at Colonial Village @ Deerfield. UPDATE - June 2008 The apartment has flooded again (this is the third time in a year) and was very similar as to what happened before. It seems that 3 or 4 other apartments in this block also flooded within a day or two of ours! If you are going to rent here do not take apartment 519 or the one above. In fact stay away from block 500 altogether. We are trying to negotiate breaking our lease (signed up til Jan 09) and moving out - it will be interesting to see what Colonial properties agree too!

Resident
2006 - 2007 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/27/2007
We moved into Deerfield last August (2006). I asked the staff person when we signed the lease whether the hot tub worked, and she said "of course!". Shortly after moving in I went down to the pool and flipped the switch, and nothing happened. I asked a maintenance guy about the problem, and he said they were waiting to try to track down the contractor who fixed the pool at some earlier date, because they thought said contractor had broken the hot tub lines. Months went by and nothing happened. Now we are moving out to buy a house, and it has been a whole year and the hot tub never worked during the whole time. Not only do the jets not turn on, but the water is only luke warm, so you get cold just sitting in there. The only people who seem to use the hot tub are high school kids who come on weekend nights, and who probably don't even live here. Interestingly, we talked to a friend who had lived in Deerfield 8 years ago, and she said the hot tub was broken then too! So it appears they just use it as a "lure" to get new residents to sign the lease. Conveniently for Deerfield, the lease includes a clause that says you can't seek damages if the amenities (including hot tub, pool, tennis courts, gym, etc) are broken. So as long as foolish people keep signing leases without checking to be absolutely sure the hot tub and other amenities work, they never have to fix it! The other problems we've had in terms of maintenance were: 1. when we moved in, the ac filter looked like it hadn't been changed in 2 years (it was really solid dust!) and the insulation around the AC intake was covered in black junk. 2. We got a clothes dryer and hooked it up and it didn't work. Long story short, it turned out that the hose line inside the wall was disconnected, and the cheap plastic hose itself was full of lint. So if I were moving into Deerfield, I would ask them to strike through the clause in the lease agreement that lets them off the hook on fixing amenities, I would ask to see the hot tub in action (and stick my foot in to see how warm/not warm it is), and I would ask to have the AC unit cleaned and the drier vent tube replaced. If the staff people tell you "I've never heard of that" on maintenance issues they are flat out lying. Also, beware the "discounted rent" trick. They get you to sign a lease at what they call "below market" rate, and then stick you with a clause saying that if you leave early you have to pay the difference between your discount rate and the so-called market rate for all the months you live there. Ask them why they can't find people to sign leases at the "market rate". Deerfield does have a great location, they just need to do a better job fixing things up.

Visited 2006 Not Recommended Reviewed 06/26/2007
My family and I just came back from trying to take a walk over past Deerfield. We were prospective tenants, and I am glad that we did not end up there. Although many of the amenitities look nice, it looks as though we will have to stay clear of the management. We had just finished going for a swim in our OWN pool and were on our way to take a walk in Duke Forest, which I believe is open to the public. We were asked if we lived there. We told them "no," and they said, "the pool is only open to our residents." Well, of course it is. They continued to tell us to go home. What is even more troubling to me is that another time we were on a walk, the management gave my son permission to come over and take bamboo for a project of his. Why would they be so mean about something so little as us walking through one day, and so nice about something like my son taking their bamboo? They need to get it together and agree on how they are going to treat people passing by. I don't want to live among people who look down on others and are such snobs that they think the only reason people would walk through would be to crash their pool. Just a warning to any of you trying to go for a walk over there in the future.

I've lived at Deerfield for a year now and I must say that it is nothing more than an average apt complex for a good price. The maintainence people always came within one day of the couple of minor complaints I had, the office staff are nice people, and the public areas are reasonably maintained. Of note, the REIT that owned Deerfield just merged with another company, so I can't say what impact that will have on management here.<br>In terms of minuses, you can occasionally hear your neighbor through the wall, but rarely and only when they are loud -------s. And you can hear your upstairs neighbor take a leak when you are in the bathroom too, which I found funny. Really my only noise compliant was the apparently 500 lb dude who lived above me stomping around.<br>Safety-wise I did see one car that was broken into, but I have had no problems. It happens to a certyain degree, but I wouldn't call it widespread.<br>And the screened in porch is great for drinking a beer and watching a thunderstorm on.<br>There are those birds that you hear in the bushes, but I can never hear them from my apartment. You do have to watch where you park though, because they crap an unbeleiveable volume. I was always able to find parking close to my place without a tree over it the birds liked.<br>There are also about 8 feral cats wandering around the property too. People feed them all the time, so I'm not sure if the management is really trying to get rid of them, or if residents really mind them. I don't really care.<br>All in all, what you see is what you get at Deerfield, no hidden surprises in my opinion.

Resident
2003 - 2004 Recommended Property Reviewed 10/27/2004
Overall this is a nice place to live. As some other reviewers have noted, however, there are some security issues to be aware of. We haven't experienced any of this first hand, but there have been incidents in the Duke Forest behind here and we've seen cars that have been broken into. I haven't heard of any break-ins or incidents within the Deerfield property. There are many dog owners here, which can be good if you like dogs. Smoking neighbors can be a problem too since the smoke can permeate through the walls to apartments above and the porches have open floors. There is also an infestation of European Starlings (birds) that the management has done nothing to control. It is a nuissance if you park your car near the trees they roost in since you will have to wash it frequently and borders on a health concern for renters and pets as you can smell their excrement on wet days. Otherwise it's a nice location, friendly management, quiet, good neighbors and reasonably priced.

2003 - 2004 Not Recommended Reviewed 03/11/2004
Make sure to read your lease carefully to be sure everything is like the management promised, otherwise you may be caught with higher rent or a longer lease than you asked for. Also if you like Alfred Hitchcock´s the birds this place is for you. Thousands of sparrows show up at 6:00 PM everyday to poop on your car and peck your head. Also don´t expect to get cell phone service with Verizon or Alltel. Just a little info so you know what you are getting into before you sign of the dotted line. That doesn´t even start with the aging buildings themselves.

Report
Resident
2002 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/12/2003
My husband & I lived at Deerfield when we transferred into the area. We are currently getting ready to move back there. We really enjoyed the multiple ammenities at Deerfield. <br> <br>Even though some people don´t like the starlings roosting, we actually loved this. It was also of great enjoyment to be able to walk right into Duke Forest. We would frequently see "families" of deer, as well as frogs, lizards, fish, birds, etc. Lots of trees...lots of bamboo! <br> <br>The screened in porches are excellent. Our cat loved it. She could sit "outside" and watch the birds & squirrels for hours on end. <br> <br>The outside storage was wonderful. We had a 1-bdrm, so we really needed the extra storage. Going back, we will get a 2-bdrm. <br> <br>The pool & hot tub were always kept very clean, as was the work-out room. The staff were very helpful & couteous. One thing mentioned in another review was the moving out notification issue. We didn´t really have a problem with this. Most other apartments have the same policy or something very, very similar. Typically, you see 30-day notice. Here, I think it was 60-day notice. <br> <br>We had no problem with noisy neighbors or being able to hear through the walls. It seemed that the people who lived near us were all single college/grad/professionals. There were some families there but not many that I saw. <br> <br>All in all, a wonderful apartment complex. It is probably the best we have ever lived in, and that is saying alot (12 in 8 yrs between the two of us).

Report
Resident
2001 - 2003 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/11/2003
Deerfield can be a great place to live; very quiet, nestled, literally in the Duke Forest, in relatively good shape, and maintained by a very friendly staff. Just make sure to scout out the individual apartment unit you are going to lease, as the condition can very from unit to unit, even within the same building. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>I lived in the 1000 building (e.g., apartments 1000 through 1012), on the third floor and faced away from the parking lot, into the lush forest only 12 or 15 feet away. The property is literally set in Duke}s private research and recreation forest (I}m not sure how the developer ever really got the land). Trailheads into the Duke Forest abut the property. I regularly heard owls, tree frogs and, during the summer, cicadas. I got no noise from the parking lot, and my neighbors were largely quiet graduate and professional students. The 900 and 1100 buildings are similarly situated. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>You would be well advised to avoid some of the units in the middle of the property that face the overgrown bamboo thickets along the stream that runs through the lot. In the bamboo thickets, hundreds, if not thousands of starlings (or "grackles") freqeuntly roost, making a lot of noise and (I think) constibuting to a sickeningly putrid smell. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>I would also advise prospective residents to either seek out third floor apartments or make sure that the air conditioners are not situated right outside their master bedrooms windows, as these can be quite loud. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>In general many of the apartments are in fairly good shape. I don}t know if the walls or thick or the neighbors are all just phenomenally quiet, but I never heard a sound out of any of them. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>The particularly large screened in porches are a plus, as the area can otherwise get buggy in the warmer months of the year. My cats enjoyed having the porch, where they could get fresh air and watch the deers and squirrels. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>The leasing office staff is very, very congenial, and accomodating. They are always understanding. The maintenance staff consists of two very nice guys who may not always get the work done in 24 hours, but who do the job right once they get to it. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>The appliances have been reliable, and are being replaced regularly over the years, as tenants cycle in and out. There are washer and dryer hookups in the individual units, but at $45 a month for the set, you}d be well advised to buy a cheap- to medium-priced washer and dryer of your own, even if you}re staying for just one year. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>The windows are not brand new, but are all double-paned. The air conditioning and heating works well. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>Parking is rarely a problem. However, for being in such a relatively secluded area out in the woods, there are the occassional rashes of break-ins into parked vehicles. I just always made a point not to leave anything visible in my car, and no one ever touched it. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>Lighting may be an issue for some people, especially young women. Some spots and pathways on the property are pitch black at night. Being a male and not from an urban area (and therefore naively unconcerned about crime), I always liked the fact that the area is not bathed in artificial light at night; it fits well with the quiet and the nature. But the dark is probably disconcerting to many people. In the past year, the management added additional lighting to some of the darkest paths. And contrary to another reviewer´s speculation, the sporadic car break-ins have not escalated to burglary of apartments and/or muggings. <br><br><br> <br><br><br>If you want a quiet apartment complex and you value trees and some nature, Deerfield}s your place. Just make sure you come see the place and a get an ideal unit, as oppossed to one that faces the parking lot or the noisy starlings.

Report
Resident
2001 - 2002 Not Recommended Reviewed 05/06/2002
Deerfield is in a great location (near Duke, in the middle of Duke Forest), but we can´t recommend it because of security issues. Apparently, this area is prone to car break-ins. Despite several complaints, nothing has been done by management to make things safer through more extensive lighting or by cropping some of the vegetation that serves as potential hiding places (as was recommended by Durham P.D.). Before signing a contract, please walk through the parking lot at night: there are numerous areas that are pitch black. So far, at least, criminal activity has stuck with car thefts and break-ins, but because of the environment, I wouldn´t be surprised if the crooks move up to apartment break ins or to muggings. Be careful!

A really nice place to live. I have no idea why a previous reviewer said they were run down--I think they´re beautiful. Generally, a quiet, peaceful place to live. A sprawling complex located right next to the Duke Forest. The management has always been friendly, and service requests are answered promptly. I haven´t noticed any sort of problem with bird noise or droppings at all. <br> <br>It´s located in a quiet, residential area. <br>Overall, pretty safe. The only problem is that there isn´t enough parking in some areas to accomodate for all the cars of the undergrads who are doubling, tripling, and quadrupling up. But it´s not a big problem. Still, it wouldn´t hurt. <br> <br>You can rarely hear your neighbors, unless their TV is on really loud or you have upstairs neighbors (in which case is sounds like herd of elephants is up there, running around at all hours.) <br> <br>Bottom line--I would recommend this complex to everyone.

At Colonial Village at Deerfield our fabulous community is conveniently located just 2 miles from Duke University, 2.5 miles from the Duke University Medical Center, and just minutes away from shopping and major interstates. If you are looking for an apartment in Durham, Colonial Village at Deerfield definitely has it all with newly remodeled apartment homes!
